questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Japanese encephalitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The transmission cycles of diseases like Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective public health measures. In the case of JE, controlling mosquito populations and minimizing human exposure to mosquito bites, especially in areas where birds are present, are key strategies in preventing the disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.
  • • Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Globus pallidus : Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.
  • • Option B. Globus pallidus
  • • Option C. Putamen : Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.
  • • Option C. Putamen
  • • Option D. Caudate nucleus : Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.
  • • Option D. Caudate nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.
  • • Option A. 5 L/min:
  • • Option B. 15 L/min : This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.
  • • Option B. 15 L/min
  • • Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.
  • • Option D. 20 L/min:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Follow up after 6 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a reproductive-aged woman with a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm and minimal symptoms, the best approach is to follow up with a repeat ultrasound after 6-12 weeks, rather than immediate intervention.
  • ➤ Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg217
  • ➤ Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg217

questions.text: A first year MBBS student presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of impending doom accompanied by profuse sweating. The episodes usually occur before her exams. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Panic disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of panic attack. Panic attack is a sudden, intense episode of fear or discomfort often accompanied by a sensation of impending doom . The symptoms during panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and feeling of unreality (depersonalization or derealization).Along with these physical symptoms there is also fear of dying, losing control or going mad .
  • ➤ a sensation of impending doom
  • ➤ palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations,
  • ➤ fear of dying, losing control
  • ➤ going mad

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 394.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: A patient with ulcerative colitis is experiencing three episodes of bleeding in stools per day but is otherwise stable. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5-Aminosalicylic acid.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis and is effective in reducing inflammation and maintaining remission in stable patients experiencing active symptoms.

questions.text: What is true about this position? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sniffing position aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, making it the ideal position for tracheal intubation

questions.text: Identify the milestone shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Transfer objects from one hand to another

questions.correct_answer: A. Transfer objects from one hand to another
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transfer objects from one hand to another

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By around 6 months of age, infants typically develop the ability to transfer objects from one hand to another, demonstrating emerging fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.
  • ➤ remit within 6 months
  • ➤ Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding in ENT emergency. On physical examination: Patient seems pale having Hb: 9 gm/dl. On CECT: a mass is seen which pushes septum to the contralateral side & anterior bowing of maxillary antrum is seen. All of the given statements are true regarding this mass except? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Most commonly seen in adolescent male

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Best treated by radiation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient’s symptoms and examination findings, including profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding, pallor, and a mass pushing the septum to the contralateral side with anterior bowing of the maxillary antrum (Colman-Miller sign), are indicative of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This condition is most commonly seen in adolescent males, can spread to the orbit and intracranially, but it is not best treated by radiation. The primary treatment for JNA is surgical resection, not radiation therapy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male: This is correct. JNA predominantly affects adolescent males.
  • • Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male:
  • • Option B. Can spread to orbit: This is correct. JNA can extend into the orbit due to its aggressive nature.
  • • Option B. Can spread to orbit:
  • • Option D. Can spread intracranially: This is correct. JNA can invade the cranial cavity, leading to significant complications.
  • • Option D. Can spread intracranially:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a condition that is most commonly seen in adolescent males and primarily treated with surgical resection, not radiation.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency by the family members. His CT scan was done which showed the following image. Which of the following can be given to this patient in this situation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitamin K

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the event of a traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, such as a subdural hematoma, Vitamin K is administered to promote blood clotting and reduce further bleeding, especially if the patient is on anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells

options.label: B
options.text: The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway

options.label: C
options.text: MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

options.label: D
options.text: MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.correct_answer: C. MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schencki

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sporothrix schenckii, the cause of sporotrichosis, typically presents as a chain of nodular and ulcerating lesions along lymphatic channels following traumatic inoculation, earning it the name "Rose Gardener's Disease."

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Septate uterus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus. A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question) If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies
  • • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.
  • • A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts
  • • On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed
  • • If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question)
  • • If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus
  • • However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice
  • • An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Uterine didelphys : Uterine didelphys appears as 2 completely separate uterine cavities on the HSG with no communication whatsoever
  • • Option B. Uterine didelphys
  • • Option C. Bicornuate uterus : Bicornuate uterus: This appears as 2 horns of the uterus which are widely separated (angle > 105 degree)
  • • Option C. Bicornuate uterus
  • • Option D. Unicornuate uterus : Unicornuate uterus: Single horn on the HSG
  • • Option D. Unicornuate uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts.
  • ➤ The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which
  • ➤ Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is the method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Leucodepleted blood

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) are caused by antibodies in the recipient's plasma reacting with the donor's white blood cells (leukocytes) present in the transfused blood. The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the leukocytes, significantly reduces the risk of FNHTRs by eliminating the trigger for the antibody reaction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Prophylactic paracetamol may help in managing fever if an FNHTR occurs, but it does not prevent the reaction itself.
  • • Option A. Prophylactic paracetamol
  • • Option B. Intravenous steroids are not typically used for the prevention of FNHTRs. Steroids may be administered in cases of severe transfusion reactions, but they do not specifically target the underlying cause of FNHTRs.
  • • Option B. Intravenous steroids
  • • Option D. Saline-washed red cell transfusion is a method used to reduce the risk of allergic reactions due to the presence of plasma proteins, but it does not directly address the issue of FNHTRs caused by leukocyte antibodies.
  • • Option D. Saline-washed red cell transfusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the donor's white blood cells, is the recommended method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions caused by antibody reactions against the transfused leukocytes.

questions.text: Vitamin B12 is found maximum in: ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Animal products

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 is naturally present in foods of animal origin, including fish, meat, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. Hence, vegetarians usually are prone to develop vitamin b12 deficiency. Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.
  • ➤ foods of animal origin, including fish, meat, poultry, eggs, and dairy products.
  • ➤ Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CPAM

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CPAM is characterized by multiple cystic, air-filled spaces in the lung and is a congenital lesion that often presents with recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

questions.text: The recommended free/residual chlorine level in the water after chlorination of a well is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Minimum Chlorine Levels : Drinking Water : The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm). Swimming Pools : A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness. Killing Cyclopes : To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm. Chloroscope device is used to measure chlorine levels in water, ensuring to meet the health and safety standards. Orthotolidine Test is utilized for measuring the chlorine content in water, confirming whether the necessary disinfection levels are being maintained. Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water, which helps determine how much bleaching powder should be added to achieve effective disinfection. The main disinfecting agent in chlorine treatments is hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which is effective in neutralizing pathogens and ensuring water safety.
  • ➤ Minimum Chlorine Levels : Drinking Water : The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm). Swimming Pools : A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness. Killing Cyclopes : To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm.
  • ➤ Minimum Chlorine Levels
  • ➤ Drinking Water : The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm). Swimming Pools : A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness. Killing Cyclopes : To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm.
  • ➤ Drinking Water : The minimum free residual chlorine level should be 0.5 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or parts per million (ppm).
  • ➤ Drinking Water
  • ➤ Swimming Pools : A minimum of 1 ppm of chlorine is required after a 1-hour contact period to ensure safety and cleanliness.
  • ➤ Swimming Pools
  • ➤ Killing Cyclopes : To effectively kill cyclopes in water, the chlorine concentration needs to be at least 2 ppm.
  • ➤ Killing Cyclopes
  • ➤ Chloroscope device is used to measure chlorine levels in water, ensuring to meet the health and safety standards.
  • ➤ Chloroscope
  • ➤ Orthotolidine Test is utilized for measuring the chlorine content in water, confirming whether the necessary disinfection levels are being maintained.
  • ➤ Orthotolidine Test
  • ➤ Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water, which helps determine how much bleaching powder should be added to achieve effective disinfection.
  • ➤ Horrock’s Apparatus
  • ➤ The main disinfecting agent in chlorine treatments is hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which is effective in neutralizing pathogens and ensuring water safety.

questions.text: A farmer had a lesion on his shoulder. Histopathological image of the lesion is shown below. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges in a skin biopsy is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma, particularly in a patient with a history of prolonged sun exposure.

questions.text: An old man presents with dyspnea and swelling of his feet. On examination, rales are heard and he is found to have an enlarged heart on chest x-ray. Which of the following will delay the progression?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Captopril

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, has been shown to improve survival and delay the progression of heart failure. ACE inhibitors like Captopril work by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and reduced workload on the heart. This class of drugs is considered a cornerstone in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HF-REF). The benefits of ACE inhibitors in heart failure are well-documented, including the 1992 study on Enalapril, which demonstrated its effectiveness as a gold standard treatment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Furosemide: A loop diuretic, Furosemide is effective in reducing symptoms of congestion and decreasing heart failure hospitalization rates but does not improve survival or delay disease progression.
  • • Option A. Furosemide:
  • • Option B. Carvedilol: While Carvedilol, a non-selective beta-blocker, has mortality benefits and improves survival in heart failure patients, it is not preferred over ACE inhibitors as the first choice for delaying heart failure progression.
  • • Option B. Carvedilol:
  • • Option C. Digoxin: This medication can reduce symptoms and heart failure hospitalizations to some extent, particularly in advanced heart failure, but it does not delay disease progression or improve survival, as evidenced by trials like the DIG trial.
  • • Option C. Digoxin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors, such as Captopril, are essential in delaying the progression of heart failure and improving survival.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked in the image ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bulbar urethral stricture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Urethral strictures, particularly in the bulbar region, are commonly evaluated and diagnosed with a urethrogram, which provides clear visualization of any narrowing or obstruction along the urethral tract.

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VDRL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives a history of bulky stools which sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bulky, greasy stools that stick to the pan (often described as "steatorrhea") can be indicative of malabsorption, a condition where the absorption of nutrients, including fat-soluble vitamins, is impaired. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.Top of Form

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 532

questions.text: Following a stab injury to the chest, the following imaging finding was noted. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hemothorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A white-out on the chest X-ray after a chest injury, especially with accompanying hypotension, is indicative of a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space.

questions.text: A dead body shows the following finding as in the image. What is the case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Smothering is characterized by facial injuries resulting from forceful application that obstructs breathing, distinguishing it from neck compression injuries seen in hanging or garrotting.

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Yellow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alcohol

questions.text: Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021) Hyponatremia Hypomagnesemia Hypocalcemia Hypernatremia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text: In the adjacent graph phase Ib represents which one of the following property? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Plasticity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phase Ib in the bladder pressure-volume graph represents the property of plasticity, where the bladder accommodates increasing urine volume with minimal increase in intravesical pressure.

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) T4b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is scheduled to receive a kidney transplant from his son who is a compatible donor. What is this type of transplant known as?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Allograft

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • An allograft is a transplantation of tissue or an organ from one individual to another of the same species but with different genetic makeup. In this scenario, the kidney transplant from a son to his father is an example of an allograft because they are both human but genetically different individuals.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Autograft : An autograft is a transplantation of tissue from one part of the body to another part of the same individual. Examples include skin grafts taken from one area of the body to treat burns in another area.
  • • Option A. Autograft
  • • Option C. Xenograft : A xenograft involves the transplantation of tissue or organs from one species to another. This type of transplant is not common in clinical practice due to the high risk of immune rejection and other complications. An example would be a pig heart valve transplanted into a human.
  • • Option C. Xenograft
  • • Option D. Isograft : An isograft is a transplantation of tissue or organs between two genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of transplant is also known as a syngeneic transplant and has the advantage of minimal risk of immune rejection due to the genetic identity between the donor and the recipient.
  • • Option D. Isograft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A kidney transplant from a son to his father is classified as an allograft because it involves the transfer of an organ between two genetically different individuals of the same species.

questions.text: Marked structure is connected to which part of basal nuclei (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Corpus striatum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The substantia nigra is connected to the corpus striatum through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is essential for motor control.

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papaya, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they could be abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counselling and information to the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) AWW

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It is the duty of the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) to provide health and nutrition education and counselling to pregnant women, addressing misconceptions about diet and ensuring they receive proper nutritional guidance. Their training includes addressing local challenges and cultural practices to promote healthy behaviors.
  • ➤ Anganwadi Worker (AWW)

questions.text: Kaposi sarcoma present in Which CD4 count? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kaposi's sarcoma in HIV patients generally presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells/mm³.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5-hydroxytryptamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine, is a crucial neurotransmitter synthesized from tryptophan and involved in numerous physiological processes. Its synthesis involves specific enzymatic actions that are targeted pharmacologically to manage various psychiatric
